Gingerbread Muffins

Jump to Recipe

Welcome to the delightful world of holiday baking with these scrumptious Gingerbread Muffins! Perfectly spiced and wonderfully moist, these muffins are a festive treat that captures the essence of the season. Infused with the warm flavors of ground ginger, cinnamon, and nutmeg, each bite transports you to a cozy kitchen filled with the aromas of Christmas. Whether you're preparing for a family gathering, a holiday brunch, or simply indulging in a sweet breakfast, these Gingerbread Muffins are sure to satisfy your cravings and warm your heart. Join me as we explore this easy-to-follow recipe that combines simple ingredients like all-purpose flour, brown sugar, and rich molasses into a deliciously spiced muffin that everyone will love. Get ready to impress your friends and family with these delightful treats that are not just easy to make but also a joy to eat!

Ingredients

all-purpose flour

For a lighter texture, consider using cake flour instead of all-purpose flour. If you need a gluten-free option, substitute with a gluten-free all-purpose flour blend. Make sure to spoon the flour into the measuring cup and level it off to avoid packing.

baking powder

Ensure your baking powder is fresh for best results. If you run out, you can substitute with 1/2 teaspoon of baking soda plus 1 teaspoon of cream of tartar for each teaspoon of baking powder required.

baking soda

Baking soda is essential for helping the muffins rise. If you're out, you can substitute with baking powder, but you'll need to increase the quantity to about three times the amount of baking soda.

ground ginger

Fresh grated ginger can be used instead of ground ginger for a more vibrant flavor. If you want to vary the spice profile, try adding a little ground cardamom.

ground cinnamon

For a more complex flavor, use Ceylon cinnamon instead of regular cinnamon. You can also mix in a bit of vanilla extract to enhance the overall taste.

ground nutmeg

Freshly grated nutmeg has a stronger aroma and flavor than pre-ground nutmeg. If you don’t have nutmeg, you can substitute with a little more cinnamon for warmth.

salt

Don't skip the salt as it enhances all the flavors in the muffins. If you're watching your sodium intake, you can reduce the amount slightly or use a salt substitute.

brown sugar

If you don't have brown sugar, you can substitute with white sugar mixed with a small amount of molasses (about 1 tablespoon of molasses per cup of sugar). This will provide the same moisture and flavor.

eggs

For a vegan option, substitute each egg with 1/4 cup of unsweetened applesauce or a flaxseed egg (1 tablespoon ground flaxseed mixed with 2.5 tablespoons water, let sit for 5 minutes).

molasses

If you don’t have molasses, dark corn syrup or honey can be used as a substitute, though the flavor will be slightly different. For a stronger flavor, try using blackstrap molasses.

milk

You can use any type of milk, including almond or oat milk for a dairy-free option. For a richer flavor, use buttermilk or yogurt.

vegetable oil

You can substitute vegetable oil with melted coconut oil or melted butter for a different flavor profile. If looking for a healthier option, you can try using applesauce or Greek yogurt.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Preheat the Oven

    Preheat your oven to 350°F (175°C). This step ensures that your muffins bake evenly. While the oven is heating, prepare your muffin tin by lining it with paper liners or spraying it with non-stick spray.

  • Step 2: Mix Dry Ingredients

    In a large bowl, whisk together 2 cups of all-purpose flour, 2 teaspoons of baking powder, 1 teaspoon of baking soda, 1 teaspoon of ground ginger, 1 teaspoon of ground cinnamon, 1/2 teaspoon of ground nutmeg, and 1/2 teaspoon of salt. Mixing these ingredients well helps to ensure that the leavening agents are evenly distributed throughout the batter.

  • Step 3: Combine Wet Ingredients

    In another bowl, mix together 3/4 cup of brown sugar, 2 eggs, 1/2 cup of molasses, 1 cup of milk, and 1/3 cup of vegetable oil until well combined. The molasses provides the signature flavor of gingerbread, so make sure it’s evenly mixed.

  • Step 4: Combine Wet and Dry Mixtures

    Gradually add the wet ingredients to the dry ingredients. Stir gently until just combined, being careful not to overmix. Overmixing can lead to tough muffins. It's okay if there are a few lumps!

  • Step 5: Fill Muffin Tin

    Spoon the batter into the prepared muffin tin, filling each cup about 2/3 full. This allows room for the muffins to rise without overflowing.

  • Step 6: Bake the Muffins

    Bake the muffins in the preheated oven for 18-20 minutes. To check for doneness, insert a toothpick into the center of a muffin; it should come out clean or with a few moist crumbs.

  • Step 7: Cool the Muffins

    Allow the muffins to cool slightly in the pan for about 5 minutes before transferring them to a wire rack to cool completely. Cooling on a rack prevents the bottoms from becoming soggy.

Frequently Asked Questions

What does 'preheat the oven' mean and why is it important?

Preheating the oven means turning it on before you start baking so it reaches the right temperature. This ensures even cooking and proper rise for your muffins.

How do I measure flour accurately?

To measure flour, use a spoon to lightly scoop flour into a measuring cup, then level it off with a straight edge (like a knife). Avoid packing it down, as this can lead to using too much flour.

What is the difference between baking powder and baking soda?

Baking powder contains both an acid and a base, allowing it to work when mixed with wet ingredients. Baking soda needs acid (like molasses) to activate. They are not interchangeable, so use what the recipe specifies.

What does 'do not overmix' mean?

Overmixing can make muffins tough. Mix until just combined; a few lumps are okay. This keeps your muffins light and fluffy.

How do I know when my muffins are done?

Insert a toothpick into the center of a muffin. If it comes out clean or with a few crumbs, they are done. If it has wet batter, bake them a few more minutes.

Can I use a different sugar instead of brown sugar?

You can substitute white granulated sugar, but it will change the flavor slightly. Brown sugar gives a richer taste and moisture.

What should I do if I don’t have molasses?

If you don't have molasses, you can use honey, maple syrup, or even dark corn syrup as a substitute. It will alter the flavor, but your muffins will still be delicious!

Is it safe to eat raw batter?

Raw batter can contain raw eggs and flour, which may carry bacteria. It's best to avoid eating it before baking.

How do I store leftover muffins?

Store muffins in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 3 days or freeze them for longer storage. To freeze, wrap them individually in plastic wrap.

What can I add to my muffins for extra flavor or texture?

You can add chocolate chips, nuts, or dried fruit to your batter. Just fold them in gently before spooning into the muffin tin.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

For gluten-free options, substitute all-purpose flour with a 1:1 gluten-free flour blend. To make these muffins dairy-free, replace milk with almond milk or oat milk, and use a vegetable oil that is free from dairy. For a lower sugar alternative, consider using coconut sugar instead of brown sugar or reducing the amount of sugar in the recipe. Additionally, you can add chopped nuts or dried fruits like cranberries for extra texture and flavor.

Pairings

For a delightful pairing with Gingerbread Muffins, consider serving them with a dollop of whipped cream or a spread of cream cheese frosting to enhance their sweetness. These muffins also pair beautifully with a warm spiced chai tea or a glass of spiced apple cider, complementing the warm spices in the muffins. For a heartier option, serve them alongside a breakfast meat like sausage or bacon, which adds a savory contrast to the sweet muffins.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the Gingerbread Muffins warm, straight from the oven or gently reheated for a cozy experience. For an added touch, dust the muffins with powdered sugar or drizzle a simple glaze made from powdered sugar and milk over the top. Present them on a rustic wooden platter, accompanied by a small bowl of assorted jams and spreads for guests to customize their muffins. These muffins make for a charming centerpiece at a holiday brunch or a festive coffee gathering.

Gingerbread Muffins

30 min
$10
200 kcal
Difficulty: 20%
Servings: 12

Allergens:

glutenegg

Dietary Tags:

vegetarian

Cuisine:

American

Course:

BreakfastSnack

Tags:

muffinsbakingeasy

Description

Warm, spiced gingerbread muffins perfect for breakfast or a cozy snack.

Ingredients

  • all-purpose flour: 2 cups
  • baking powder: 2 tsp
  • baking soda: 1 tsp
  • ground ginger: 1 tsp
  • ground cinnamon: 1 tsp
  • ground nutmeg: 1/2 tsp
  • salt: 1/2 tsp
  • brown sugar: 3/4 cup
  • eggs: 2
  • molasses: 1/2 cup
  • milk: 1 cup
  • vegetable oil: 1/3 cup
